pageContext.desc: Religious writings by the New York state Welsh Congregationalist pastor and publisher of a pro-abolition Welsh religious reform magazine.

pages.transcription:
Psalm 84th[sto]  Delivered Aug 3. 1794
Along society Nov 9th
How amiable are thy [sic] Thy Taberna=
cles, O Lord of Hosts. --
The writer of this psalm is supposed
to be the man after God's own heart.
It is supposed also, that he compos=
ed it, in his exile from the Tabernacle
& worship of God, occasioned by the
conspiracy & rebellion of his Son Ab=
salom -- In this affected situation
he expresses the pious affection, and
breathing of his soul to God, in the
fifth & second verses of this psalm
How amiable are thy Tabernacles
O Lord of Hosts -- My soul longeth,
yea, even fainteth for the courts of the
Lord -- My heart & my flesh crieth
out for the living God -- These ar=
dent desires of the psalmists heart.

towards these objects - express a ele=
vation of his piety -- and set before
us in a stricking point of light, the
general nature of christian exercis=
es under all similar circumstances.
In the words of the Lent are no=
ticable two particulars --
1st The object of the Smss admira=
tion (viz) the Tabernacle --
This [word stricken] building was set up
by a pattern immediately given
by the Lord of Hosts himself the God of Israel.
it was dedicated wholly his immediate
service, & he owned it for his habita=
tion - And hence it is [unknown word], thy Ta=
bernacles  O Lord of Hosts -- it is expres=
sed, plurally (most probably) in reference
merely to a different apartments contain=
ed in it, & the different services assigned
to each of them--
2ndly We may notice in what respect

this object is declared to be admirable
(viz) in its beauty -- also a delight &
pleasure  enjoyed in it; How amiable 
this is --  how desirable  are
thy Tabernacles O Lord -- the delight
& satisfaction they are capable of af=
fording is not eve to be expressed,
The obseration [sic] which naturally
arises from the text is this (viz)  To
the people of God, his temples are very
amiable or desirable  --
In attending to this observation it is
proposed to contemplate only t reasons
why t temples of t Lord of Hosts are
so desirable by all t children of God --
To which will be added some reflec=
tions -- 
The reasons why t temples of [unknown]
or t Lord of Hosts are so desirable to
all his children may be all comprehend=
ed in two general ones -- (viz) The

privileges which are set forth or ma=
nifests in these temples -- & secondly
their hearts being prepared by t spirit
of God to relish & be delighted with these
privileges -- These are t two general
reasons why they are so amiable and
desirable -- The latter of these reasons
why the temples of God are to desirable
to his children - (viz) that their hearts
are prepared by t spirit of G. to relish
those privileges is necessarily supposed
[word faded and struck through] without this they would
not be his children -- the privileges of 
t sanctuary would not be delightsome [sic]
-- they would not give them a divine
seraphic pleasure -- on t other hand these
privileges would be [unknown], dull, and
wearisome -- In t language of t [Phs]
Behold their ear is uncircumcised - & they
cannot hearken: behold t word of the
Lord is unto them a reproach they have
no delight in it -- [unknown] all [unknown]

true children or people being pre=
pared by his spirit have a feeling
in unison with t [unknown]: Say he
my soul longeth, yea, even fainteth
for to courts of t Lord -- This pre=
paration therefore being understood, it
will not not be necessary to dwell up=
on this part of t subject -- The
first general reason why t Temples
of God are so desirable to his children
(viz) on acct of t privileges which
are manifested in them need attention
The inquisitive mind wishes to know
what are some of those privileges
These will be mentioned in six pas=
[unknown] each of wh. make t sanc=
tuary of God very amiable & [word struck through and faded]
desireable to his people and
{unknown][unknown] Jesus, who is t Lord of Hosts
always dwells in a gracious man=
ner in such places & temples as he

owns for his -- & there meets his people
The Lord of Hosts dwelt in the
Tabernacle by his gracious presence
[word struck through and faded] in a pillar of a cloud
In t same manner also he entered
into t temple built by Solomon --
These tabernacles he owned for his
Of the latter it is said, And the
Lord appeared to Solomon & said
Now have I chosen & sanctified
this house that my name may
be there forever: & mine eye and
mine heart shall be there perpe=
tually -- If thou wilt walk before
me as David thy Father walked
& do according to all that I have
commanded thee -- In t gospel
day we find that God is pleased
[several words scratched out] to honor any
place or temple with his gracious
presence when his people meet
for his service says he where two
or three are met in my name there

am I min the midst -- But more
especially is he present in Temples where his
people steadily resort & attend most
comformably to his will, in all his in=
stitutions -- He walks, amidst his gol=
den candlesticks - & says in the lan=
guage of t [unknown] This is my rest for=
ever, her will I dwell for I have
desired it -- & he loveth t gates of
Zion more than all the dwellings
of Jacob -- Now t privilege of meet=
ing God & enjoying t manifestations
wh he makes of himf. to his desciples
is esteemed by them of infinetely great=
er value than all things besides.
To see the thing of Glory in his beauty
is pleasant beyind description -- Says
David O God my soul thirsteth for
for thee -- my flesh longeth for thee
in a dry & thirsy land where no wa=
ter is To see thy power & thy glory
so as I have seen thee in t Sanctu=

tuary -- This seeing of God in t sanctu=
ary hides t [unknown] of every other
object & depreiciates every other kind
of enjoyment so much that they are
not to be mentioned as bearing any
proportion to t nature of this --
On [unknown] of this privilege of meeting God [unknown] temples are very
[word scratched out] amiable & desirable: --
2ndly they not only meet God in his
sanctuary & behold his glory -- but
they are admitted free access to him
in prayer ==
says the Apos in with the Father and
with his Son Jesus Ct -- In this com=
munion by prayer - They have opportu=
nity to present before Ct. immediately the
whole compass of their desires concern
ing thems for time & eternity -- like=
wise t whole compass of their desires
concerning their nearest friend & dearest
objects around them -- & likewise their
desires concerning the chh [abbreviation of "children"?] of God and
all mankind - and all this with the

most perfect assurance of being heard and [unclear] in every proper desire and wish. Ct. says [unclear] 18th-19th. If two of you shall agree on earth as touching{?] anything they shall ask - it shall be done for them of my father who verily I say unto you whatsoever ye shall ask the Father in my name he will give it you. Now this privilege of communion with Ct. in the places where he meets his children, is unspeakably great. Ct. says by his [unclear] i will make them joyful in my house of prayer. How pleasant and delightsome must it be to commune with him who is Father of their spirits and

[unclear] This seeing of Ct. in a [unclear] hides a [unclear] of every other object and depreciates every other kind of enjoyment so much that they are not to be mentioned as bearing any proportion to a nature of this on acct of this privilege of meeting Ct. His temples are very amiable and desirable
2) They not only meet Ct. and behold his glory but also have the privilege of holding communion with him by prayer. Our communion says the [Apo.?] is with the Father and with his son Jesus Ct. In this communion by prayer they have opportunity to [unclear] before Ct. immediately whole compass of their desires concerning them. For time and eternity - likewise a compass of their desires concerning their nearest friends and dearest objects around them - & likewise their desires concerning the [unclear] of God and mankind and all this with the

most perfect assurance of being heard and answered in every proper desire and wish. Ct. says [unclear] 18th.19th - If two of you shall agree on earth as touching anything they shall ask - it shall be done for them of my Father who is in Hn. This reflects social prayer in who his people are agreed - & concerning any matter in who they shall mutually agree to lay before him.He says again by Holy Ghost - before they call I will answer, while they are yet speaking I will hear saith the Lord - & again "Verily verily I say unto you whatsoever ye shall ask the Father in my name he will give it you. Now this

him who has redeemed them fr eternal destruction by his blood - how pleasant to find him caring for all their afflictions - entering into all their joys & sorrows & comforting them with a token of his mercy & love? How comforting to leave all [unclear] concerns of their dearest connections in his hand, to leave the conflicts & distresses of his [unclear] with him who is perfect in wisdom & cannot err. How safe to leave in his hands a world lying in wickedness - [unclear] [unclear] together with their almost infinite connections, in who the children of Ct hold communion with him in prayer, make [unclear] place of his sanctuary very amiable and desirable.
3dly In the sanctuary of Ct. [unclear] his children with all necessary instruction concerning their duty to him.These instructions they receive with a spiritual[unclear] & relish

Divine truth, in its various subjects & connection proves a quickening word to them - All divine truths honor God - this gives the joy - the way of salvation it overcomes them with unspeakable qualitive - all circumstances in the plan of salvation and persecution of it shine in their view, with the wisdom and infinite mercy of God- and hence their hearts burn within them as the disciples going to Emmaus- the word of God, one spirit and life - It is a quickless word, by which theirafectio and graces are enlivened, and strengthen- and enabled more vigorously to uplift the temptation who left them for the wolrd, the felsh and Satan - Hence says the swift they word is sweeter to one than the honey and the honey comb - Here after they find the

& they with him. These outward signs wash away no sin, nor make any atonement - they are designed to express outwardly benefits [unclear chased by Ct. body & blood: and to represent & confirm application of those benefits previously applied to heart. In these [unclear] transactions how infinitely unworthy do his children feel:yet how joyful? Most deeply distressed with a sense of sin, they rise proportionally in holy admiration of redeeming love -That sovereign love wh. saves them fr. the depths of misery - By these outward solemn transactions between [unclear] & their own souls, they grow confirm in the {unclear] of gospel & live upon hidden manna - they live by that bread wh. came down from [unclear] wh. gives life to all who partake

[unclear] to submission to lawful authority & benevolence to all -. In t sanctuary Ct dwells as a purifier of sin by his word -as a  fountain for cleansing by his atonement & as a well of water for refreshment & satisfaction: He says by his Spirit the Lord hath chosen Zions: he hath desired it for his habitation: This is my wish forever: herewith I dwell for I have desired it - I will abundantly bless her provisions, and I will satisfy her poor with bread. I will also clothe her priests with [unclear]; & her saints shall shout aloud for joy -How grt is this privilege of [unclear] & quickening received fr. t. oracles of divine truth? A life of experience can only teach it
4thly In the sanctuary Ct.seals his covenant with his people - by his sacriments. Here He sups with them

of it. This privilege os upping with Ct. & giving all to him, in covenant & receiving a taste & confirmation of all spiritual blessings, is beyond expression. This makes t. temples of Ct desirable & beautiful
5th In t. sanctuary where Ct dwells in t birthplace of saints - says Ct by his [unclear] of Zion it shall be said this & that man, was born in her & [unclear] highness [unclear] shall establish her. The Lord shall count - when he writeth up the people - that this man was born there- This is a matter of unspeakable joy to his people: there is joy in Hn  over one sinner that repenteth - equally so here among t people of God -  according to their grace & knowledge of it. Instances of this nature give fresh vigor, refreshment & comfort as shows the power of Ct. as plainly as to raise

t dead . It shows the truth of his promise that his [unclear] shall never fail & that no[unclear] of earth or hell shall prevent t accomplishments of all his glorious designs of saving all who repent. This continued miracle in raising men spiritually dead to life is a mean of confirmation who invigorates to faith of his people & excites peculiar animation. To mention [unclear] one more. In the sanctuary is t place where the people of God enjoy t greatest communion with t [unclear] above - in theirpraises and halalujahs to God. Here is t place where they gain new strength to gloryfy God & prepare for Hn. These privilege made t [unclear] feel t amiableness & beauty of Ct's  tabernacles & to say Blessed are they that dwell in thy house

measure will feel as unclear they will say, O God How amiable are thy tabernacles My soul longeth yea even fainteth for the court of the Lord my heart & my flesh without? for thee.  3d We see likewise the gratitude wh. becomes those to express who are about to be blessed with the privileges for wh. they long.

Blessed is t man whose strength is in thee; in whose heart are t ways ofthee. They go fr strength to strength; everyone in Zion appeareth before God. For a day spent in they court is better than a thousand. I had rather be a door keeper in t house of my God than to dwell in t tents of wickedness.
Improvement - If the privileges to be enjoyed in the sanctuary of Ct. are so great & calculated to give his children such happiness; then see that those who are blessed with a tabernacle of worship when they can [unclear] enjoy these privileges are infinitely favored
2 - If t privileges of Cts sanctuary are so grt & desirable then we see that those who are deprived of them in any
[Blank]

Pm [unclear] 2d - 6th  delive. [unclear] July 20 1806
He shall come down like rain upon t mown grass, as showers that water t earth. These words are supposed to represent t influences of the Holy Spirit refreshing t souls of God's children. In order to contemplate them with improvement it is necessary to consider two particulars -
1.Wherein mown grass or the earth represent the hearts of men 
II. where rain and shower falling upon earth and grass represent t influences of the

spirit falling on t hearts of men. To which will be added as improvement
I . We are to consider wherein mown grass or earth represent t hearts of men. And [unclear] in their surroundings - The field wh. is laid waste by t mower. Scythe presents a barren prospect. The remaining stalks appear as if they would never revive under the scorching beams of t sun [doodle] The earth likewise in its simple natural state is barren, it knows no such thing as pleasant fruits, grass, grain, herbs, fruit & trees grow not upon it spontaneously, so also t hearts of men - they are utterly destitute of right affections toward God

These grow not spontaneously the fruits off spirit which appear in right affections of t heart, & guide all the faculties of men in a way of obedience to God do not spring from  this soil- not t least possible fruit of this kind is to be seen. But the natural heart like t barren earth produces only weed, nettles, briars & thorns of sin, its affections are corrupt. They lead them to break every holy duty & commit. So the natural hearts of men are barren of any good fruit, ever since sin entered t world [unclear] glory has departed. They have nothing but barrenness left. They have no love, delight, joy, peace & comfort in God. They have no holy gratitude, trust or submission to God. They have no true repentance, faith, hope or christian humility. They  have no patience, fortitude or resignation to divine will or any other [unclear]

sin without cesation – It is like uncultivated wilderness, when every tree, plant, an shrub grows wild – & every ravenous beast, bird, & serpent have their unclear, & barren to the unclear waste – The unclear heart, unclear & fraught with evil defies, wild imaginations ungovernable fashion pride, malice, envy, unclear and hypocricy may well be, unclear It's barren of all good – & yeelds only unclear, his = To unclear barren earth unclear Frequently in a unclear condi=

Zion under the burning heart of the sun - As the stalks of grap after the mower appear withering scorched and lifeless - so the natural heart often appears disconsolate & Joy unclear under a single of its sins, & the wrath of God - Outward enjoyments now, are unclear and burdensome - a fearful looking for of Judgment & fiery indignation awakens the most distressing fear - The terror of A Lord take hold - & A guilty soul find nothing to shelter it fr. impending wrath; except God's unclear sovereignty - The hope from its own righteous unclear is cut off & every refuge of deception fails - it withers

like the mown grap.
The earth also parched with the sun represents the natural heart under affliction - When God is pleased to take away earthly comforts, such as near friends - children, property, or reputation - the springs of Joy so to natural man are dried up - so also when sickness wastes his strength & appetite, & makes him a burden to himself, then his Joys and comfort are dried up as the earth is dried of its moisthure - he is in a famishing condition - his sorrows shroud him in sackcloth & he sits in a region & shadow of death - Again - The earth may illustrate the natural heart in one more respect - . As it is barren

of good fruit & often his is a parched condition under t. heat of the sun so also it is frequently very hard & rocky - The natural heart, destitute of grace is hard like a rock - or encrusted ground. no seed, trees, or plants can fall into or grow on the rock - or parched ground, so no seeds of divine truth - precepts or commands - providences or calls of God can enter a natural heart or impress it so, as it shall receive it & bring forth fruit. So the Holy Spirit (Zechariah 7.12) They made their hearts as an adament stone unclear they shant hear the same & of words which A Lord of HOsts hath sent in his spirit by a former unclear

Who are repeatedly called upon to break up then fallow ground, & to sow not among thorns - meaning, t. parched ground of t. heart, which receives not t. seed of divine truth - The stony ground hearers were the stony in heart Thus we see the mown grap & t earth represent t hearts of natural men in their barrenness of spiritual fruits - their unclear & Joyless state under a sense of God's wrath, & outward affliction, & also their harness is unclear & unclear of sin, & impressions from divine unclear -
